parts: Name this most common protein in mammals.
Collagen possesses this geometric structure, which was erroneously proposed as the structure for DNA by Pauling and Corey.
One reason the triple helix structure of DNA was rejected was because these anions repel each other, preventing the three chains from staying together.
Name this thinker who described his namesake dialectic in Science of Logic and wrote Phenomenology of Spirit.
In Phenomenology of Spirit, Hegel used this term to describe the force which moves great historical figures to change the course of the world.
This American thinker observed the overpowering democratic geist of the modern era and predicted its inevitable dominance in his 1992 book The End of History and the Last Man.
Name this Nickelodeon cartoon about Timmy Turner and his two magical companions.
In the Fairly OddParents, Timmy is tormented by this sadistic baby-sitter. Chip Skylark writes a song describing this character as icky.
In a 2008 special, Timmy’s fairy godfather Cosmo gave birth to this baby fairy. Unlike other fairies who use wands, this magical infant grants wishes with a rattle.
The prominence of this late 1700s German movement was ended when Goethe and Schiller transitioned to Weimar Classicism. Its name is usually translated as “Storm and Stress.”

Horace Walpole’s The Castle of Otranto is considered to be the first novel of this movement, whose other novels like Mary Shelley’s Frankenstein demonstrate its elements of gloom and fear. Its name comes from a style of architecture.
This 1950s American movement was closely intertwined with the counterculture of the time. Its prominent members include Allen Ginsberg and Jack Kerouac.

answers: defenestration (or being thrown out of a window)
parts: Name this massively destructive religious war which decimated much of Central Europe in the seventeenth century. It was ended by the Peace of Westphalia
The Thirty Years’ War began after this action was inflicted on two Catholic emissaries of Emperor Ferdinand II in Prague. Unlike a similar event in 1419, none of those targeted for this action died.
This 1620 battle during the Thirty Years’ War was a major victory for Ferdinand II and the Catholic League, but its potential impact incited more Protestants nations to join the fray.

answers: Moonlight Sonata (accept Piano Sonata No. 14; or Opus 27, No. 2)
parts: Name this work by Beethoven named for a phenomenon shining on Lake Lucerne.
This baroque composer was known for his 555 keyboard sonatas, although he composed in other forms as well.
This four-movement sonata for piano and violin was a collaborative work between Robert Schumann, Johannes Brahms, and Albert Dietrich. It was named for a German phrase meaning “free but lonely.”
This unit, symbolized with a capital R, was formerly used to measure exposure to gamma and x-rays, which were discovered by its namesake.
This constant, symbolized R-sub-H for hydrogen, appears in its formulator’s equation for calculating the wavelength of Lyman and Balmer lines.
R is a constant in the equation PV equals nRT, which describes these theoretical substances that are not impacted by intermolecular forces.

answers: In a Grove (or Yabu no Naka)
parts: Name this author of “Hana” and “Rashōmon” who names the highest Japanese award for literature.
This Akutagawa work follows a murder from the perspectives of a woodcutter, a buddhist priest, a homen, a criminal, a girl, and the ghost of the dead man, Takehiro.
These two items are found next to Takehiro by the woodcutter; name either. One of these items is not mentioned by any other character, and one is used to bind Takehiro.
Name this notoriously inescapable federal prison in San Francisco Bay, nicknamed “The Rock.”
Perhaps the most famous Alcatraz inmate was this Chicago gangster and bootlegger who spent four and a half years at Alcatraz after being convicted of tax evasion.

Though Alcatraz was supposedly escape proof, Frank Morris and these brothers attempted to escape The Rock in a prison-made boat in 1962. The actual fate of Morris and these brothers remains unknown. Note: Last name sufficient.

answers: Hans Holbein the Younger (prompt on Hans Holbein, do not accept “Hans Holbein the Elder”)
parts: Name this artist of Body of Dead Christ in the Tomb along with a depiction of two men with a globe, astrolabe, and lute in The Ambassadors.
Holbein painted “Virgin and Child” with this fruit. Sandro Botticelli created multiple works with this fruit, including a famous Madonna of this fruit.
This artist's Dream Caused by the Flight of a Bee prominently features a pomegranate. He created elephants with spider-thin legs in his Swans Reflecting Elephants.
Name this East African nation, which suffered a terrible famine in the mid 1980s and was earlier ruled by Haile Selassie.
Ethiopia fell under this regime following the deposition of Haile Selassie. Led by Mengistu Haile Mariam, this communist dictatorship killed hundreds of thousands of people in the Qey Shibir terror.
The Derg frequently battled separatists from this region, which achieved independence from Ethiopia in 1993. Today, sporadic violence persists between Ethiopia and this country.
Name these mythological beings generally imagined with the torso of a woman and the tail of a fish.
These Celtic maidens of the sea often marry the men who steal their seal skins, at least until they can return to the water.
These Japanese “mermaids” are often depicted as hideous creatures, but those who catch and eat them are said to have eternal youth and a long life.
Name this legal system based on Islamic teachings. Many contemporary groups support this legal system, despite its controversial hudud punishments.
Within Sharia, this term denoted the process of reaching legal decisions when the Qur'an or Hadith are unclear. The “gates” of this process were supposedly closed in the 10th century.
Legal opinions derived from Sharia are known by this term. Ayatollah Khomeini called for the execution of Salman Rushdie in one of these rulings in 1989.
This author became the first African American to win the Nobel Prize in Literature for novels such as Beloved and Song of Solomon.
This poet was the first African American woman to have her work, specifically Poems on Various Subjects, Religious and Moral, published.
This man wrote one of the first widely disseminated slave narratives, an autobiography billed as an “Interesting Narrative” of this man’s life.
Name these rectangular arrays of numbers.

The determinant of a matrix can be found by this method, which requires finding the determinants of matrices left after crossing out a row and a column. When the namesake entities are multiplied by 1 or negative 1, the resulting values are called cofactors.
This rule is used to find solutions to systems of linear equations written as a matrix. It expresses each solution as a quotient of two determinants.
Name this play by Chekhov about the purchase of Madame Ranevsky’s estate and the subsequent cutting down of the title area.
This other Chekhov work ends with the suicide of Constantine Treplev after Nina reveals her love for Trigorin. This play takes its name from a certain beachside pest.
In Chekhov's “The Bet,” this character volunteers to live in solitary confinement for 15 years as part of the title bet.

This revolutionary song was written to celebrate an upcoming war with Austria and Prussia, and today is France’s national anthem. It urges “To arms, citizens” and calls for “impure blood” to soak French fields.
“Das Lied der Deutschen” is the national anthem of this nation, but that song’s original lyrics demanding continental domination were removed following World War Two.
José Martí wrote the poetic lyrics of this song amidst the Cuban War of Independence. The Sandpipers sang a notable version of this song, which remains widely popular in Cuba.
Name this artistic duo from the “Golden Age of Musical Theater” who created such hits as Oklahoma, South Pacific, and the The King and I.

This second musical by Rodgers and Hammerstein premiered in 1945. This show profiled the ill-fated romance of Julie Jordan and Billy Bigelow and contained songs like “If I Loved You” and “You’ll Never Walk Alone.”
This final Rodgers and Hammerstein musical opened in 1959 and became a box office hit six years later. In this show, Maria leaves an abbey to tutor the Von Trapp children.
This capital of Australia was designed as a “garden city” by architects Walter and Marion Griffin. Its location arose from a compromise between Melbourne and Sydney.
Like Canberra, this Brazilian capital was pre-planned. Designed by Lúcio Costa and Oscar Niemeyer, this fourth largest city in Brazil is carefully divided into sectors based on utility.
Perhaps the world’s most famous planned city is Washington DC, designed by this French engineer. This man mapped out the city’s “grand avenues,” and a major DC plaza is named for him.

answers: nuclear fission (prompt on “nuclear reaction”; do not accept or prompt on “nuclear fusion”)
uranium-235 (accept U-235 ; do not accept or prompt on “uranium” or “uranium-238” or “uranium-239”)
parts: Name this process discovered by Otto Hahn and Fritz Strassman which enabled the creation of atomic weaponry.

Nuclear fission is initiated by the absorption of this sub-atomic particle, which causes the nucleus of an atom to become unstable and fission. The resulting reaction releases both energy and more of these particles.

To create a traditional, non-plutonium nuclear weapon, a core must be enriched in this fissile isotope until it constitutes about 90%. In the Manhattan Project, gaseous diffusion was used to enrich it, although today centrifuges are more common.
Name this particle that carries negative charge.
This property of an electron is equal to Planck’s constant divided by its momentum. This is the wavelength associated with a massive particle.
Louis de Broglie names a causal interpretation of quantum mechanics with this physicist, whose namesake mechanics involves particles accompanied by pilot waves.
